summary.p: On the return journey from Freiburg im Breisgau via Basel to Burgundy, Cousin wanted to take the opportunity to write to Bullinger, as [Johannes] Gast is sending a messenger [...] to Zurich. - Cousin thanks Bullinger for the goodwill shown to him over many years and for his letter on the question of the Lord's Supper. However, he can only express his gratitude inadequately. - Bullinger should take care of his health. - Cousin has entrusted Gast with a gift for Bullinger. Greetings to [Theodor] Bibliander and [Konrad] Gessner.

div.p: Greetings. On my return journey from Freiburg im Breisgau through Basel to Burgundy, most illustrious man, when our Gastius said he would send a messenger to Zurich tomorrow, and asked me if I wanted anything, I did not want to let him leave without a letter from me, expressing my feelings towards you, even though I believe you have no doubts about my respect for you.

For your kindness, with which you have embraced me continuously for many years, I give you eternal thanks. You recently provided a candid example of this in your letter to me about your views on the Eucharist. I wish, my dear Bullinger, that I could someday show myself to be not ungrateful!

As God loves me, the will is never lacking; if I cannot demonstrate it in deeds - since you are greater than our efforts can aspire to - you will still praise the effort, for as he said, in great matters, even the will is enough.
My dear Bullinger, take care, as much as you can, to stay healthy, and consider that nothing is more pleasing to us than your health, nothing can be announced more gratefully.

In Basel, on the 4th day before the Ides of March in the Christian year 1545, hastily, as you see. I have entrusted Gast with a gift for you; I ask again and again that you consider it kindly. Greetings to all friends, especially to Bibliander and Gessner.
Yours sincerely, Gilbert Cousin of Nozeroy.
To Lord Heinrich Bullinger, incomparable defender of true theology and Christianity, his esteemed lord and teacher.
